Project Number: 39287 
Regional Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
February 2009 
 
 
 
 
Strengthening the Implementation of the Asian 
Development Fund Grant Framework in ADB's 
Developing Member Countries

  ADF  –  Asian Development Fund

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  allocates  Asian  Development  Fund  (ADF) 
resources in accordance with its performance-based allocation (PBA) policy1 and revised ADF 
grant framework.2 As agreed during ADF X negotiations, revisions to the PBA policy were 
approved  by  ADB's  Board  of  Directors  on  11  November  2008.  The  revised  ADF  grant 
framework, approved in September 2007, aligned ADB’s grant allocation policies with that of 
International  Development  Association  (IDA)  14 3   and  the  debt  sustainability  framework 
developed by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and World Bank.4 The debt sustainability 
framework relies on debt sustainability analyses (DSAs), conducted by IMF and World Bank for 
IDA-only and poverty reduction and growth facility-eligible countries, usually once a year. Under 
the revised ADF grant framework, ADF grants are now allocated solely on the basis of reducing 
the risk of future external debt distress, with countries of high and moderate risk receiving 100% 
or 50%, respectively, of their allocation in ADF grants.  
 
2.  Adopting and directly linking ADF grant allocation to the debt sustainability framework 
has significant operational and financial implications for ADF countries and ADB. The first 
concern  is  the  debt  sustainability  framework’s  implementation,  as  ADB’s  fiduciary 
responsibilities require its staff to confirm DSA results. This means that ADB staff must now 
participate in the DSAs. Second, ADB’s ADF grant framework is also aligned with IDA’s policy 
on nonconcessional borrowing by IDA grant recipients, implying that countries receiving IDA 
(and ADF) grants may face sanctions by IDA—and due to its alignment, also by ADB—if they 
borrow on nonconcessional terms. Borrowing on nonconcessional terms may harm a country’s 
debt sustainability and undermine IDA and ADB’s efforts to improve a country’s external risk 
rating.5  
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Policies that determine the level of ADF grant and loan mix are either new to ADB clients 
or have recently been adjusted. ADF clients need to understand the policies on five levels: (i) 
the nature of the revised performance criteria as well as the basis for their revision; (ii) the 
framework for resource allocation decisions; (iii) links between the PBA policy and the revised 
ADF grant framework; (iv) IDA’s policy on nonconcessional borrowing, as ADB’s is fully aligned 
with it; and (v) links between the policies, their outcomes, policy dialogue, and country strategy.

5  IDA has identified a set of criteria by which nonconcessional borrowing will not trigger sanctions. The Operations 
Committee, upon the recommendations of a group of representatives from departments within the World Bank, 
decides whether sanctions should be imposed on a case-by-case basis. Sanctions imply either a hardening of IDA 
(ADF) terms, or a reduction in grant volume. Countries that do not receive IDA grants—though they are IDA-grant 
eligible—do not fall under the nonconcessional borrowing policy, i.e., they will not face sanctions from IDA.

2   
4.  Moreover, given important changes in the PBA policy, such as the cap on the largest 
ADF borrowers and the phase-out of post-conflict ADF grants for Afghanistan and Timor-Leste, 
it  is  essential  that  borrowing  countries  understand  how  the  revised  PBA  policy  works. 
Strengthening government officials’ knowledge of the PBA system will help them explain the 
technical reasons for changes in country performance assessment (CPA) ratings to civil society 
organizations  that  sometimes  use  the  published  CPA  ratings  to  monitor  a  government’s 
performance.  In addition, since the biannual ADF allocation for 2009–2010 is based on the 
revised grant framework, it is crucial that ADF clients understand the links between the PBA 
policy and the revised ADF grant framework as they have a direct impact on future resource 
allocations. 
5.  While only one ADB developing member country is receiving debt relief under the highly 
indebted poor country initiative,6 good debt management is also important for other ADF-
recipient countries, including those that currently are not classified as having a high risk of future 
debt distress.  
6.  The concept for this regional capacity development technical assistance7 (TA) emerged 
during ADF X discussions. Borrower representatives expressed that ADF clients need to gain a 
better understanding of the revised policies and their implications, especially those on resource 
allocation. Donor shareholders support deeper client engagement in the process, and client 
interest was strong both in recent government official induction courses held in October 2008 
(where the CPA and DSA were briefly introduced) and in earlier PBA workshops (such as the 
one held in November 2008 in Bangkok, funded by an earlier regional TA project).8 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The purpose of the TA is to contribute to more effective use of ADF resources, thereby 
indirectly contributing to poverty reduction. The outcome is expected to be greater awareness of 
how ADB allocates its ADF resources, improved technical skills for debt sustainability analysis, 
and  better  knowledge  of  the  revised  PBA  policy,  debt  sustainability  framework,  and 
nonconcessional borrowing policy. Key inputs will be training, technical workshops, and TA to 
improve debt management in key ADF-only recipient countries. These inputs will improve the 
opportunity for policy dialogue between respective country teams and ADF clients.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The  key  outputs  of  the  TA  will  be  developing  in-country  capacity  for  better  debt 
sustainability  analysis  and  understanding  of  the  PBA  policy  and  the  revised  ADF  grant 
framework, resulting in improved policies and institutions. Reports, such as DSAs that are 
stand-alone documents and are produced as part of IMF article IV missions, will be completed 
with an increased degree of country ownership and understanding of the technical models used. 
Debt management will also be improved through training in information technology and various

assessment tools. Key activities will be two regional PBA policy and ADF grant framework 
workshops for Pacific (with about 24 participants) and non-Pacific countries (with about 32 
participants), which will be jointly facilitated with staff from the World Bank, and up to two debt 
management training programs (or workshops) in regional hubs (with about 10–15 participants 
each). Where there is strong country demand, debt management training will not be limited to 
ADF-eligible countries only. Each borrowing country will be invited to nominate two persons to 
attend a designated workshop. Workshops on the PBA policy and ADF grant framework are 
expected to last 2 days, while training on debt sustainability analysis and related topics is 
expected to be 3–5 days. Resident mission and headquarters staff involved in CPAs and DSAs 
will participate in these workshops. 
9.  Activities covered during the PBA policy and ADF grant framework workshops will 
(i)  describe the process of preparing CPAs; 
(ii)  explain approved revisions to PBA systems, and where possible, in collaboration 
with the World Bank; 
(iii)  describe links to IDA policies; and 
(iv)  explain  the  revised  ADF  grant  framework  and  the  process  of  replenishment 
negotiations.  
 
The activities during the debt management training/workshops (both technical sessions and 
more generalist training) are expected to  
 
(i)  explain links between the DSA, the revised ADF grant framework, and ADF grant 
allocation; 
(ii)   explain ADB’s approach to nonconcessional borrowing in ADF-recipient countries; 
(iii)  apprise governments of ADB’s new role in conducting DSAs; 
(iv)  explain the mechanism behind debt distress risk rating and how ADB’s can 
sometimes vary from that of the World Bank; 
(v)  provide  training  to  government  officials  to  improve  capacity  in  analyzing  the 
sustainability of public debt, including a hands-on tailor-made training program on 
World Bank-IMF DSA for low-income countries; and 
(vi)  introduce government officials to other debt management tools that are being 
developed by other international financial institutions and relevant agencies, such 
as the debt management performance assessment.  
 
10.  ADB’s PBA and DSA focal points will take the lead in organizing the workshops. Given 
the alignment between ADB’s PBA policy, the ADF grant framework, and nonconcessional 
borrowing  policies  with  those  of  IDA,  ADB  staff  will  explore  collaboration  with  IDA  in  the 
workshops and training seminars. To support ADB staff, consultants will assist in preparation for 
the workshops. Assistance of resource persons from public agencies and international financial 
institutions will also be required. Smaller  breakout sessions and hands-on training in key 
analytical packages will supplement the presentations. Participants will receive a package of 
information materials and other relevant documents. There is also scope to support, on a pilot 
basis and where required, international consultants to support capacity building in debt offices 
relating to improving the quality of external debt data.

4   
C.  Cost and Financing 
11.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $400,000 to be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s TA funding program and will be financed from the Technical Assistance Special Fund IV. 
This will support travel costs, accommodation, and per diem for the participants. It will also 
cover payment for consultancy services and costs of resource persons for the PBA policy and 
ADF grant framework workshops and debt management trainings, and other related capacity-
strengthening tools. The detailed cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
12.  ADB will be the Executing Agency. The Resource Mobilization and Allocation Unit in the 
Strategy and Policy Department will administer the TA, in close cooperation with the Treasury 
Department's  ongoing  TA 9,  operation  departments,  resident  missions,  and  host  country 
governments. It is also anticipated that IDA will participate in the workshops. The TA will be 
implemented by ADB in consultation with host governments of each workshop location. 
13.  The  TA  implementation  period  will  be  from  February  2009  to  February  2011. 
Collaboration  with  host  governments  is  expected  to  involve  mainly  logistical  and  protocol 
aspects of organizing the workshops and trainings. The TA will engage for about 60 days a 
national consultant for each PBA policy and ADF grant framework workshops. ADB will also 
engage a national consultant for about 60 days for each of the debt management trainings. ADB 
also  plans  to  engage  international  consultants  for  the  on-the-job  training  in  strengthening 
external debt data statistics, as well as resource persons to conduct debt management trainings 
in specific hubs and, where required, to take part in more specific debt management tasks in 
selected ADF-recipient countries. The terms of reference for the consultants are outlined in 
Appendix  3.  The  consultants  will  be  engaged  as  individuals  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). Disbursements 
under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement 
Handbook.10  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis for 
Strengthening the Implementation of the Asian Development Fund Grant Framework in ADB’s 
Developing Member Countries, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  National consultants will be required for each of the performance-based allocation (PBA) 
policy and Asian Development Fund (ADF) grant framework workshops and debt management 
trainings, each for a period of about 60–90 working days. The terms of reference are described 
below.  
 
A.  National Consultant for the PBA Policy and ADF Grant Framework Workshops and 
Debt Management Trainings (300 person-days) 
2.  The national consultant will: 
 
(i)  help prepare informational and learning resources for these regional workshops; 
and 
(ii)  assist in the administrative and logistical arrangements for these workshops, and 
provide support during their implementation. 
 
B.  International Consultants to Improve Debt Management in Selected Developing 
Member Country (6 person-months) 
3.  The international consultant will:  
 
(i)  strengthen compilation of data (e.g., timeliness and accuracy) in national debt 
offices; and 
(ii)  strengthen  analytical  skills  by  training  officials  through  relevant  International 
Monetary Fund and other international financial institution tools.  
 
C.  Resource  Persons  for  Improved  Debt  Management  and  Analytical  Skills  (60 
person-days, including preparation) 
4.  The resource persons will: 
 
(i)  prepare  debt  management  instruction  and  materials  for  the  regional  debt 
management training workshops (home office), and 
(ii)  provide  debt  management  training  during  the  appointed  workshops  and/or 
seminars.
